prompt: Choose the correct verb: Each of the students ____ ready for the test.
explanation: Each of the students is treated as singular here, so use 'is'.

prompt: Choose the correct verb: Neither of the options ____ ready for the test.
explanation: Neither of the options is treated as singular here, so use 'is'.

prompt: Choose the correct verb: A number of people ____ ready for the test.
explanation: A number of people is treated as plural/collective in this sentence, so use 'were'.

prompt: Choose the correct verb: The list of items ____ ready for the test.
explanation: The list of items is treated as singular here, so use 'has'.

prompt: Choose the correct verb: The team ____ ready for the test.
explanation: The team is treated as plural/collective in this sentence, so use 'have'.

prompt: Choose the correct verb: My brother ____ ready for the test.
explanation: My brother is treated as plural/collective in this sentence, so use 'have'.

prompt: Choose the correct verb: The results ____ ready for the test.
explanation: The results is treated as plural/collective in this sentence, so use 'are'.

prompt: Choose the correct verb: Everyone ____ ready for the test.
explanation: Everyone is treated as singular here, so use 'is'.

prompt: Choose the correct verb: The book ____ ready for the test.
explanation: The book is treated as plural/collective in this sentence, so use 'do'.

prompt: Choose the correct verb: One of my friends ____ ready for the test.
explanation: One of my friends is treated as singular here, so use 'is'.

prompt: Choose the best option: I ____ (finish) my practice set already.
explanation: Use present perfect for an action completed with present relevance: 'have finished'.

prompt: Choose the best option: When I arrived, the class ____ (start) already.
explanation: Past perfect shows the earlier past action before another past action: 'had started'.

prompt: Choose the best option: She ____ (study) every night this week.
explanation: Use present perfect continuous for an action that started in the past and continues: 'has been studying'.

prompt: Choose the best option: By next month, we ____ (complete) the full plan.
explanation: Future perfect: 'will have completed' for completion before a future time.

prompt: Choose the correct option: She wants to buy ____ umbrella because it is raining.
explanation: Use 'an' before a vowel sound (umbrella).

prompt: Choose the correct option: ____ Nile is one of the longest rivers in the world.
explanation: Use 'the' with names of rivers: the Nile.

prompt: Choose the correct option: He is ____ honest person.
explanation: 'honest' starts with a vowel sound (silent h), so use 'an'.

prompt: Choose the correct option: I go to ____ school by bus.
explanation: No article for institutions used for their primary purpose: go to school.

prompt: Choose the correct preposition: She is good ____ solving word problems.
explanation: We say 'good at' + gerund.

prompt: Choose the correct preposition: The test begins ____ 9:00 a.m.
explanation: Use 'at' with specific times.

prompt: Choose the correct preposition: I have been waiting ____ you for 20 minutes.
explanation: We wait for someone.

prompt: Choose the correct preposition: They arrived ____ the airport early.
explanation: Use 'arrive at' for specific places.

prompt: Choose the best option: If I ____ more time, I would review the reading passages again.
explanation: Second conditional uses past simple in the if-clause: 'If I had... I would...'.

prompt: Choose the best option: If you had followed the plan, you ____ the model easily.
explanation: Third conditional: if + past perfect, would have + past participle.

prompt: Choose the best option: If it ____ tomorrow, we will study at home.
explanation: First conditional uses present simple in if-clause: 'If it rains...'.

prompt: Choose the correct form: He suggested ____ a short quiz before starting the lesson.
explanation: After 'suggest', use a gerund: 'suggested taking'.

prompt: Choose the correct form: They decided ____ early to avoid traffic.
explanation: After 'decide', use to-infinitive: 'decided to leave'.

prompt: Choose the correct form: I can't afford ____ this course twice.
explanation: After 'afford', use to-infinitive.

prompt: Choose the correct form: She enjoys ____ to podcasts while studying.
explanation: After 'enjoy', use a gerund.

prompt: Choose the best option: The student ____ score improved the most followed the daily plan.
explanation: Use 'who' for people as a subject.

prompt: Choose the best option: This is the notebook ____ I bought yesterday.
explanation: Use 'that' (or which) for things in an object role.

prompt: Choose the best option: The teacher to ____ we spoke was helpful.
explanation: After a preposition, use 'whom' for people.

prompt: Choose the best option: I met a learner ____ strategy was surprisingly simple.
explanation: Use 'whose' to show possession.

prompt: Choose the best option: I was tired; ____, I finished the full practice set.
explanation: 'However' shows contrast.

prompt: Choose the best option: Study the rules ____ you start solving models.
explanation: Use 'before' to indicate sequence.

prompt: Choose the best option: He reviewed carefully ____ he wouldn't repeat the same mistakes.
explanation: Use 'so that' to express purpose.

prompt: Choose the best option: ____ the lecture was long, it was extremely useful.
explanation: Use 'Although' to introduce contrast.

prompt: Choose the best option: This plan is ____ than trying random sources.
explanation: Use comparative with 'than': 'more effective'.

prompt: Choose the best option: Of all the sections, reading is the ____ for me.
explanation: Use superlative: 'the hardest'.

prompt: Choose the best option: I feel ____ confident after reviewing my mistakes.
explanation: Comparative idea: 'more confident'.

prompt: Choose the correct option: Neither the teacher nor the students ____ (be) late today.
explanation: With 'neither...nor', the verb often agrees with the closest subject ('students'): 'are'.

prompt: Choose the correct option: A number of questions ____ tricky, so I reviewed them twice.
explanation: 'A number of' is plural: 'are'.

prompt: Choose the correct option: The news ____ encouraging for many test-takers.
explanation: 'News' is uncountable singular: 'is'.

prompt: Choose the correct option: I look forward to ____ your score improve soon.
explanation: 'Look forward to' + gerund: 'seeing'.

prompt: Choose the correct option: He has lived here ____ 2020.
explanation: Use 'since' with a starting point in time.

prompt: Choose the best option: She ____ (not/finish) the reading set yet.
explanation: With 'yet', present perfect is common: 'hasn't finished'.

prompt: Choose the best option: She ____ (not/finish) the reading set yet.
explanation: With 'yet', present perfect is common: 'hasn't finished'.

prompt: Choose the best option: We should focus ____ our weakest section first.
explanation: Focus on something.

prompt: Choose the best option: We should focus ____ our weakest section first.
explanation: Focus on something.

prompt: Choose the best option: She ____ (not/finish) the reading set yet.
explanation: With 'yet', present perfect is common: 'hasn't finished'.

prompt: Choose the best option: We should focus ____ our weakest section first.
explanation: Focus on something.

prompt: Choose the best option: The strategy, along with the daily quizzes, ____ very helpful.
explanation: The main subject is 'strategy' (singular), so use 'is'.

prompt: Choose the best option: We should focus ____ our weakest section first.
explanation: Focus on something.

prompt: Choose the best option: The strategy, along with the daily quizzes, ____ very helpful.
explanation: The main subject is 'strategy' (singular), so use 'is'.

prompt: Choose the best option: If you ____ earlier, you would have avoided rushing.
explanation: Third conditional needs past perfect: 'had left'.

prompt: What is the main idea of the passage?
options: Urban Gardens is explained with its benefits and some challenges.
Urban Gardens is impossible to improve.
Urban Gardens is only useful for children.
Urban Gardens is a temporary trend with no value.
explanation: Main idea questions ask you to summarize the passage in one sentence. Choose the option that matches the overall message.
passage:
Title: Urban Gardens

In many large cities, small community gardens have become more than a hobby. They offer residents a place to grow vegetables, share tools, and meet neighbors. Researchers have noticed that these gardens can also reduce stress and encourage healthier eating. However, running a garden is not always simple: volunteers must coordinate schedules, protect plants from pests, and sometimes negotiate with local authorities about land use. Even so, the popularity of urban gardens continues to rise, especially in neighborhoods where fresh produce is expensive.

prompt: Which statement can be inferred from the passage?
options: Small habits can create noticeable long-term results.
Practice is unnecessary if you have talent.
explanation: An inference is a logical conclusion based on evidence in the text (not directly stated, but supported).

prompt: What is the main idea of the passage?
options: Sleep and Memory is explained with its benefits and some challenges.
Sleep and Memory is impossible to improve.
Sleep and Memory is only useful for children.
Sleep and Memory is a temporary trend with no value.
explanation: Main idea questions ask you to summarize the passage in one sentence. Choose the option that matches the overall message.
passage:
Title: Sleep and Memory

Scientists have long suspected that sleep plays a key role in learning. During deep sleep, the brain appears to organize new information and connect it with older memories. In one experiment, students who slept well after studying performed better on a test than those who stayed awake. The researchers did not claim that sleep replaces practice; instead, they argued that sleep makes practice more effective. This idea explains why intense last-minute studying, especially late at night, often leads to poor recall the next day.

prompt: Which statement can be inferred from the passage?
options: Small habits can create noticeable long-term results.
Practice is unnecessary if you have talent.

options: Renewable Energy is explained with its benefits and some challenges.
Renewable Energy is impossible to improve.
Renewable Energy is only useful for children.
Renewable Energy is a temporary trend with no value.
explanation: Main idea questions ask you to summarize the passage in one sentence. Choose the option that matches the overall message.
passage:
Title: Renewable Energy

As the cost of solar panels falls, more homes are generating their own electricity. Some families even sell extra power back to the grid. Critics worry about the initial investment, but supporters point out that long-term savings can be significant. In addition, small solar systems reduce demand during hot afternoons, when air conditioners use the most electricity.

prompt: What is the main idea of the passage?
options: Digital Minimalism is explained with its benefits and some challenges.
Digital Minimalism is impossible to improve.
Digital Minimalism is only useful for children.
Digital Minimalism is a temporary trend with no value.
explanation: Main idea questions ask you to summarize the passage in one sentence. Choose the option that matches the overall message.
passage:
Title: Digital Minimalism

Many people keep dozens of apps on their phones, yet they regularly use only a few. Digital minimalism is the practice of reducing unnecessary apps and notifications to regain focus. It does not reject technology; rather, it treats technology as a tool that should serve clear goals. Users often report feeling calmer after turning off constant alerts.

Title: Public Libraries

Modern libraries are no longer quiet rooms filled only with books. Many offer internet access, workshops, and spaces for group study. For students, libraries provide a distraction-free environment and free resources. Some librarians also teach short lessons on how to evaluate sources, which is increasingly important in an age of misinformation.

Title: Nutrition Labels

Reading nutrition labels can help consumers make better choices, but labels can also be confusing. For example, a product may appear healthy until the serving size is examined. Health experts recommend comparing products using the same serving size and paying attention to added sugar, which can hide under several names.

Title: Water Conservation

In dry regions, small changes in daily habits can save large amounts of water. Fixing a leaking faucet may seem minor, yet it can waste many liters over time. Some cities have introduced programs that reward households for installing efficient showerheads and watering gardens at night, when evaporation is lower.

Artificial Light is impossible to improve.
Artificial Light is only useful for children.

passage:
Title: Artificial Light

Artificial light allows people to work and travel after sunset, but it can also disrupt sleep. Exposure to bright screens late at night may delay the release of melatonin, a hormone associated with sleepiness. Some experts suggest using warmer screen colors in the evening, while others advise avoiding screens entirely before bedtime.

passage:
Title: Teamwork

Teams can solve complex problems faster than individuals, but only when communication is clear. If roles are not defined, some members may do too much while others do too little. Effective teams set goals, agree on deadlines, and create a simple method for sharing updates. This reduces misunderstandings and saves time.

prompt: What is the main idea of the passage?
options: Volcano Monitoring is explained with its benefits and some challenges.
Volcano Monitoring is impossible to improve.
Volcano Monitoring is only useful for children.
Volcano Monitoring is a temporary trend with no value.
explanation: Main idea questions ask you to summarize the passage in one sentence. Choose the option that matches the overall message.
passage:
Title: Volcano Monitoring

Volcanoes rarely erupt without warning, but the signals can be subtle. Scientists monitor ground movement, gas emissions, and small earthquakes near a volcano. While these signs do not guarantee an eruption, they help authorities decide whether to evacuate nearby communities. Accurate communication is essential, because false alarms can reduce public trust.

passage:
Title: Learning a Second Language

Learning a second language is not only about memorizing vocabulary. Learners also need repeated exposure to patterns, such as word order and common expressions. Many successful learners keep a small notebook of errors they make and review it weekly. This habit prevents the same mistakes from appearing again and again.

options: Recycling Limits is explained with its benefits and some challenges.
Recycling Limits is impossible to improve.

passage:
Title: Recycling Limits

Recycling is often presented as a simple solution, yet not all materials are equally recyclable. Some plastics can be recycled only once, while others are difficult to process. Experts argue that reducing waste in the first place is more effective than relying on recycling alone. Still, recycling programs can lower the amount of trash sent to landfills.

prompt: What is the main idea of the passage?
options: Climate and Mosquitoes is explained with its benefits and some challenges.
Climate and Mosquitoes is impossible to improve.
Climate and Mosquitoes is only useful for children.
Climate and Mosquitoes is a temporary trend with no value.
explanation: Main idea questions ask you to summarize the passage in one sentence. Choose the option that matches the overall message.
passage:
Title: Climate and Mosquitoes

As temperatures rise in some regions, mosquitoes may survive longer and spread into new areas. This can increase the risk of mosquito-borne diseases. Public health agencies use data on temperature and rainfall to predict mosquito activity and plan prevention campaigns. Community awareness, such as removing standing water, also plays an important role.

Space Debris is only useful for children.
Space Debris is a temporary trend with no value.
explanation: Main idea questions ask you to summarize the passage in one sentence. Choose the option that matches the overall message.
passage:
Title: Space Debris

Thousands of small objects orbit Earth, including old satellites and fragments from past collisions. Even a tiny piece of debris can damage a spacecraft because of its high speed. Engineers are exploring ways to remove debris, such as nets or magnetic systems, but the challenge is costly and requires international cooperation.

prompt: Which statement can be inferred from the passage?
options: Small habits can create noticeable long-term results.
Practice is unnecessary if you have talent.
explanation: An inference is a logical conclusion based on evidence in the text (not directly stated, but supported).

explanation: Main idea questions ask you to summarize the passage in one sentence. Choose the option that matches the overall message.
passage:
Title: Music and Mood

Music can influence mood in surprising ways. Fast rhythms may increase energy, while slow melodies can calm the mind. Some therapists use music to help patients manage stress. However, researchers note that personal preference matters: a song that relaxes one person may annoy another.
